citation.article-title: Isolation and characterization of a novel mesophilic, fresh-water methanogen from river sediment Methanoculleus oldenburgensis sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Methanoculleus oldenburgensis sp. nov.
Methanoculleus oldenburgensis (ol.den.bur.gen.sis., M.L. masc. adj. oldenburgensis pertaining to Oldenburg, a city in Northwest Germany)
The cells are non-motile, fimbriated irregular cocci 0.5-1.5 μm in diameter, occurring singly, seldom in pairs.
The cell envelope consists of a protein S-layer and is easily lysed by detergents, e.g. Triton X-100 (0.01 %) and sodium dodecyl sulfate (0.01%).
Growth occurs in a synthetic, acetate-containing (0.1% w/v) mineral medium with H2-CO2 and/or formate as substrates.
No growth and methane formation was observed with methylotrophic substrates or secondary alcohols alone.
Growth occurs within the temperature range of 25°C to < 50°C, with an optimum at 45°C The optimal pH-value for growth is between 7.5 - 8.0 and the pH range is 6.5- 8.5.
Sodium chloride is not required and is inhibitory at levels exceeding 1.5% (w/v).
The cells contain putrescine, symhomospermidine and spermine as typical polyamines.
The polar lipid pattern is similar to the one of the Methanoculleus species.
The G + C content of the DNA is 48.6 + 1 mol% (Tm).
The habitat of strain CB-1 is the sediment of the Hunte river near Oldenburg.
Strain CB-1 has been deposited in the collection Deutsche Sammlung von Mikroorganismen und Zellkulturen GmbH, 3300 Braunschweig, FRG, under DSM 6216.
